name: Blockland
description: Blockland is a non-linear sandbox game with no set goals, giving players the freedom to design and construct elaborate structures. Styled as a tiny minifigure, players build inside of the virtual world using bricks reminiscent of toy blocks.

I got into Blockland back in 2005 when I was just 11 years old, and back then it was a free game that looked just like Legos, and ever since then, I've seen people and friends come and go, rivalries with other games that were only similar in the concept of 'sandbox game where you can build and destroy anything'.  As someone who had practically no social interaction prior, this game and it's community actually helped me grow and mature as a person, I've met so many cool, intelligent, talented and funny people over the years and even became friends with some of them, and it got me in to basic C++ scripting, 3D modeling, audio editing, and even a bit of video making. It is at this point that I feel like I owe my life to this game. Even to this day, I find myself coming back to this game every now and then to build something, to create a new mod, try out someone else's mod, or to just goof about on servers.  This game, for me, and several others, is like the 'Hotel California' of video games, you may leave, you may stop playing for a while, but you always come back, for one reason or another. Even those who don't like this game or it's community and get banned for their actions keep spending more of their money just to come back, it's like a drug that you just can't quit!  For the 11 years I've been at this game, I've been very active on the message boards, and it's been such an interesting, funny, and unique community over the years, and I've been able to watch it grow and change as time went on, like, I've never been so invested in a community as I am with Blockland's.  I do hope that Blockland becomes as popular as games like Roblox, some may disagree with me on this, that they prefer this smaller and more controlled crowd of people, but Blockland really does deserves a bigger audience, it actually is a fun and amazing game. It may be slow and tedious to build something big and amazing, but that's how building is with every sandbox game, ' Rome wasn't built in a day .', and if building isn't your thing, there's just a big variety of gamemodes and servers out there that are PvP death-matches, role playing servers, a boss battle server, knife fights in the sky with grappling hooks, dog fights, single-lap races, multi-lap races-- there's just so many to choose from, you're bound to find something you like!  The biggest problem with the game is ' time ', what time of the day you get on matters, what time-zone you live in compared to other people matters, what day of the week it is matters, time is a big factor in finding busy and/or good quality servers.  While I recommend this game, I also commend checking out the message boards, there you can chillax and talk amongst others that play the game, get help with the game, post pictures of things you built or did, download add-ons or other sorts of mods that people make, or just talk about whatever else, about other video games, or about drawings or other sorts of creative things you or other people do!

Make sure you have a friend(s) who own this game or you literally will have to win the lottery on finding someone who is cool enough to accept you as one of their own. You will most likely not get anywhere, otherwise.  Sales for this game are sparse, but still happen occasionally. Try and snag it then if you're not willing to lay down $10 for it. I bought it when it was $20/pre-greenlight, though, so whatever floats your boat.  Community is pretty ♥♥♥♥, though, so good luck.

Blockland has a bit of a history. In 2005, it was a little work-in-progress building game on the Torque Game Engine. Being an alpha, it had (here comes a massive understatement) quite a few mods that generated a larger following. The full game released in 2007, and much more polished than anything seen before. Streams of updates from the game's sole creator (with some collaboration thrown in) in the past six years have created a unique game that nothing can hope to come close to.  So, what's the main point? Blockland is That Game Where You Build Stuff. It's all on you, and the community. Using LEGO-like blocks to create structures in online multiplayer may sound mundane on paper, but the online part is where it really shines. The amount of creativity Blockland players have is nothing short of amazing. User-created add-ons like weapons and vehicles are plentiful, allowing for different and fun gamemodes within buildings YOU create, and an 'events' system gives way for even more creativity within builds.  An accessible sandbox game for such a price is almost a steal.

So basically what Blockland is, is a first-person sandbox multiplayer create-your-own-anything game. SOUND FAMILIAR??? You control inhabitants known as 'Blockheads' and build anything, Yup, quite familiar. HOWEVER, you do NOT start in a pre-generated world. It is a flatgrass-style area you find yourself in. All saves you make are only builds, and not whole worlds, which is not as convoluted as Minecraft as all you can do to get a build you made is straight-up load it like a schematic.  Now for building things and designing games, functions, etc.: You can see building is quite advanced and more difficult than Minecraft. But it's great if you want a first-person Sandbox building game with more detailed models than Minecraft, as Minecraft is all 1-meter blocks and very flat compared to Blockland blocks. For functions, you can use a Wrench to make blocks emit light and particles, as well as implement functions to make games and programming. Minecraft pretty much does the same thing with Command Blocks, etc., but IMO, Blockland is more simple than Minecraft in terms of functions. Because Minecraft's functioning requires specific functions and assets, sometimes extra mods, to make a good mechanism.   I MIGHT be missing something here, as I have never tried such functions myself in Minecraft, but I should say that you have no information to design Minecraft functioning whatsoever unless you use the internet, which I don't really like doing given how the Minecraft community is nowadays.  Blockland may be difficult and advanced to build than Minecraft, with all the little blocks to use and everything, but I found that it's much simpler to build what I want without getting my ♥♥♥♥ kicked in Minecraft trying to obtain a specific asset for my work. People would say Minecraft is waaaay better than Blockland that they hate this game, but I'm one of the few who played it back then and had a good time, speaking of which...  Everybody knows Minecraft is the way to go besides Blockland. But for the nosalgia, or stuff Minecraft can't as mentioned above, I play this. I'm one of the few who actually like this game and I'm glad it doesn't have a fustercluck of a community like Minecraft, which is what I was anxious to point out. I really admire how quiet and underrated Blockland and its community is compared to Minecraft, and even Roblox as well. (I also played Roblox and it was pretty cheezy). Minecraft's majority of fans has pretty much bubble-bursted, where Blockland is 'Just right', however getting beat down by Minecraft.  But I will say this as I finish up this review.  Blockland came years before Minecraft . It is not exactly a ripoff of Minecraft, which I apparently am seeing an award of which this game attained. I give this game a thumbs up, as it was what got me going before Minecraft was all the rage. This is just my opinion though. This game is mind-blowingly awesome. You want to abuse rapid firing rockets via an event system or just want to build a humble little home? Well, here's your solution.  I reccomend the first thing you'd want to do is go to Start A Game and click on the Tutorial gamemode. Then start this game and make it singleplayer and follow the steps shown on screen.  The game uses an easy to install add-on system, which is basically finding the Steam directory on your computer (Windows: Steam > SteamApps > Common > Blockland) and dragging and dropping your selected file into the AddOns Folder. I think this system will eventually be modded and changed to work with Steam Workshop like Garry's Mod. Once you have the right addons and knowledge of how to use them, the possibilities for a good server are endless.  The building mechanics are very simple once you get the hang of them - simply using the numpad/your selected control scheme to maneuver the blocks into the right place and pressing Enter when your ''Ghost Brick (Invisible brick you will see when you click the ground to move a block around) is above a support or another block. Then you can use the Paint Can (default key is E) to paint this block a selected colour.  Physics-wise, this game is absolutely mad. If you think it's hilarious to have your car flung into oblivion then this game is definitely the one you want. This also kind of falls into the category of graphics. This game's visuals are not the best, but definitely better than Minecraft's. (Sorry Notch.)  The game uses an eventing system which is a basic scripting mechanism. I think there should be a guide somewhere on the magic that is the Steam page, and that also tells you the rest about the game.    Also, little LEGO guys. They're so cute.   10/10 would build giant castle again.

I'll be very simple with the review since it's not a game that you need to over-complicate or go too in-depth with the details of. Blockland is a lego-like sandbox game in which you can create and design any kind of world or server you could ever desire. The game can be compared to the sandbox 'Garry's Mod', which also centers on a player-driven system.  Like Garry's Mod, this game is somewhat of a niche, yet because of it's marketed open-endedness and scope, as well as low price and system requirements has been marketed to mass public. And like Garry's Mod, this is a game for specific people, and not the mass market.  The community has been accused of being focuses of drama and controversy and the forum and game policing has said to be flimsy at best, but this is a community driven game, again, like Garry's Mod. And on top of that, this game was developed in a time period in which indie games struggled quite a bit to get on their feet. This combined with the rare lifespan that this game has exhibbited has picked up a lot of baggage over the years, just like anything would. And the high social learning curve that comes with this game isn't exactly friendly to new players. What I mean is that each server is maintained and controlled be either a board of admins that the host has chosen to moderate and maintain the server, or a singular admin. How that admin wants to host and represent that server is up to them. People who like the hosts ideals will likely drift towards the servers with those admins, making sub-cultures in the game world.  The best thing for a new player to do is find a server with friendly new players and slowly intigrate into the community, otherwise you will most likely irritate the sometimes easily irritatable inhabitance of the game.  All in all, coming from a 'veteran' player that watched this game grow and grow over the years, I'd say that it is enjoyable, so long as you can find a server community that you can intigrate with, you will have no problem with the community. As for the game, it's a high customisable sandbox game. That's pretty much the depth of it.

Preface: I've had this game since 2010 back in v16 and it has changed a LOT since then. I've watched the community grow and change and I've probably spent several hundred hours on the game before it came to Steam.  Blockland is a creative sandbox game created in 2004 by Badspot. A lot of people say it's kind of like Lego Garry's Mod, which isn't far from the truth. I love this game to pieces and always have, but it does have certain flaws that can seriously hinder the experience at times.  The game is great because you can do nearly anything, but the community is a bit... strange, at times. There are two groups of people in the game: the noobs that don't know how anything works, and the old-timers that are either very supportive of newcomers or are spiteful towards them. There's not much middle ground between these groups and quite a lot of the veteran players have left the game since v21 was released, a few months before the game came to Steam.  The biggest actual gameplay drawbacks will be very obvious within the first couple hours of playing: a bad physics engine and subpar graphics. The physics engine has been buggy and unpredictable since the game's creation, although the graphics are actually substantially better now than before.  Possibly the only thing that has really kept me playing the game this long is the giant amount of user-made content that can be found on the official forums. The custom add-ons really bring the game to life and it's somewhat bland without them. Nearly every popular server runs many add-ons, allowing for an even more custom and unique experience.  Due to its Garry's Mod-like sandbox nature, Blockland has also inspired several notable video makers on YouTube, including Teneksi, Filipe1020, 8bitcube, Flubbman97, SirHerg1, and others.  I'm trying not to be too wordy, so I'll just do pros and cons now cuz I'm boring like that.  Pros:  - Great building system allowing for near-endless creativity - Lots of great public servers to join - Huge catalog of mods and add-ons - Not difficult to set up a server (can be tricky sometimes if your internet is weird) - Community has lots of nice people that will help new players learn the game - Low price  Cons:  - Buggy physics - Average graphics - Controls can take a while to get used to - Not frequently updated (back in the day there was usually an update every couple weeks or so, but there hasn't been anything major since January 2014 as of this review) - Community has lots of trolls  The community is both a pro and a con because depending on who you meet, it could really go either way.  Overall, I would say the game is definitely one of my favorite games of all time and even if you don't like it, it's only $10 USD spent. Troubleshooting Advice for Mac Users  I want to point out that I had serious problems running this game after selecting the Full Screen setting under the options. It crashed the application. I ended up having to hit 'Command' & 'Q' to exit the application on my iMac. After that, the application kept crashing and wouldn't boot anymore.  I had to delete the application's preferences file to get it to boot up in the default settings again. I had to keep doing this until I got the game working in the desired resolution and video settings. Below is the location of the Blockland prefs.cs file in OS X version 10.6.8, in case you run into this problem:  username/Library/Application Support/ Steam/SteamApps/common/Blockland/config/client/prefs.cs  The game is running fine now in window mode only though… I believe the only thing that actually crashed the application was trying to run it in Full Screen mode. I have everything turned up as high as I can. The games graphics are a little dated, but they still look okay.  Again, you only need to either rename or trash the Blockland prefs.cs file to get the game to launch again in the default settings mode. After you get the game settings the way you want them and it's not crashing anymore you can safely play the game. Just do not try running it in Full Screen mode again. [If you dislike reading seemingly irrelevant information you are free to skip to the bottom of this review. There you will find my recommendation. Thank you!]  So this game has been one of my favorite building games of all time. Starting in 2010 along with the majority of what I would say was our community, I bought the original Blockland and was having a great time. Things were getting done, updates being made. There were these classics maps I'll never forget: the Bedroom, the Kitchen, and the Slopes. I enjoyed this game, and I was estimated to be playing it about 10 hours a day or more. (Update: Many people don't believe I played this game as long as I claim. The truth is, Blockland existed before (its release on) Steam. For this reason, Steam has not registered all my hours from when I played it before. I only recently migrated to Steam Blockland from the original Vanilla Blockland. Hope that clears things up!)  It took some time but an insightful man by the name of Ephialtes in-game decided to build Blockland a new system. I believe it was around 2011-2012 that this became widely-used. It was called Return to Blockland, and was basically the Steam client for Blockland before Blockland was actually on Steam. It had a 'Workshop' (servers that hosted add-ons you could directly download from), Add-On Manager, Friends client, global IRC chat, chat rooms, easy-to-use settings system for your server, add-on preferences manager, and so much more. It was the true revelation of Blockland's existence. It brought upon a new experience for the Blockland community, and gave it a modern feel.   Then this game went on Greenlight.   That officially marked the downfall of RTB, which would eventually be shut down because Steam replaced 1/3 of its functionality. There would no longer be a place to manage your add-ons, chat globally with other BL users, find your friends (since they would no longer be on RTB and you didn't know if they had Steam), and last but not least, you could no longer manage your server like you used to.  That probably drove me away the most. I stuck around for a bit, hosted a multitude of mildly popular servers as well as a 32/32 player MERP server that consisted of most of my time. After about four months, I kinda lost interest and began the process of leaving the BL community. I left a legacy, but even that would soon be forgotten...  So you know that game called Minecraft? I ended up spending almost all of my time on that. I hosted some very popular servers on Minecraft, met some great friends, and was enjoying it. I almost forgot about Blockland completely, but then my friend (who shall remain nameless) decided to get Blockland after I showed him a fun little gamemode on it called Renderman. He got it, and when I saw that he did, I decided to hop back on and play with him... but I didn't do much otherwise.  I truly came back about two months ago. I began hosting my MERP server, probably just to feel the nostalgia and see all the empires that had been built on it. A friend of mine by the name of Amir (a full-time player of my server back when it was popular) happened to stop by. We had an awesome reunion, played a bit of MERP (not really. Just remarked on how sucky our builds were), had a lot of fun. I began playing Blockland much more.  And then I stopped. Garry's Mod took up my time. I managed a community on there and couldn't depart from them. But that wasn't the only reason.   I lost interest.   So anyways, if you got to the bottom of this review reading through an incredibly long backstory and wondering why the heck I'd write a story like that, I congratulate you. You have the patience of a... you, but none of this was really a review, was it?  So here's my take on the game.    If you want to play a game with a large amount of active community supporters/respectful, mature players, don't get this game.  If you want to play a game where you build anything and can do anything (with the help of a bit of programming knowledge or the visually-based event system), get this game.  If you want to play a game where servers are always full and there is an easy way to liven up your game with user-created add-ons, don't get this game.  If you want to play a game where you can host a server of any kind, have some fun with Pirate Ship DM gamemodes, and basically shoot your friends with laser pistols and horse rays (yeah, they turn them into a horse), this game IS FOR YOU.  BUT. If you want a game that will keep you interested for years to come, always ready for that next update, always ready for that next big thing... don't get this game. It's unkempt, uncombed, and unfathomably stagnate.  But I might be wrong. What if YOU are the next big thing?     In my opinion, this game is NOT recommended due to the lack of interesting things that may be found in Blockland.

This game has one of the more complicated methods of building. It sincerely rewards talent and planning as to there isn't really a matter of rote time spent building but in how it is built. This isn't just like the best minecraft creations which are...just large, but how the design is implemented. As far as the community??...mostly young children, of elementary age, always has been, always will be.   The problem is the game has lost its appeal to those older people who were contributing it its isolated and beautiful pre-steam 'RTB' development. A comprehensive add-on manager with community updates turned this into one of PC gaming's best kept creative secrets, just like Battlefield 2's Sandbox mod and the original Garry's Mod. But like all great things, it must come to an end. (Christ I'm not even 18 yet and I've seen countless communities die out, makes me feel like an old man) The steam transfer was relatively flawless, but avid players looked on with mostly hype among a few skeptics, me one of them who feared the worse. It didn't come eventually but the RTB admins stopped developing, and the whole project folded. Communities who tried to stick together became separated into cliques of steam friends, with their own pathos and memes wanting ♥♥♥♥-all to do with anybody else.  This is a game where my City server, under the name Anonymousca4 took around a year in 2012 to come out with any real results, and to be honest, simply wonderful, it was like that city of lego I had in my basement as a child but with no fear it would need to be cleaned up. The community had its trolls, which were only really seeking some thrills, and its children, which after some coddling didn't ruin the mood. It was all good then, add-ons were inspired and modular, meaning along with a good brick-builder you could mimic or even produce any game mode or setting imaginable, making this a sort of macro-game among its users, as in this was about the only game they actively played. Community involvement and even drama felt inclusive, hard to avoid which resulted in some great times like Blockoworld 2011, a god damn in-game convention showcasing different servers, players and talents.   Can it be a fantastic game? I'd be one of the first to tell you so, but can I recommend it without a proper source of new content and a fractured playerbase. Got some friends looking for a lan game or party game, then there should still be hope, but as far as a multiplayer game it has lost its charm that provided me with some great moments in middle school.
